title: Banksia violacea
text:
Banksia violacea, commonly known as violet banksia, is a species of <a href="shrub">shrub</a> or tree in the plant genus "<a href="Banksia">Banksia</a>" (family <a href="Proteaceae">Proteaceae</a>). It generally grows as a small shrub to 1.5 m (5 ft) high with fine narrow leaves, and is best known for its unusually coloured dark purple-violet <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a>s. The colour of the inflorescences, short leaves, and flattened follicles which are sticky when young, help identify this species from others in the field. It is found in low <a href="shrubland">shrubland</a> in southern regions of <a href="Western%20Australia">Western Australia</a> from <a href="Esperance%2C%20Western%20Australia">Esperance</a> in the east to <a href="Narrogin%2C%20Western%20Australia">Narrogin</a> in the west, growing exclusively in sandy soils.
First described in 1927 by the West Australian botanist <a href="Charles%20Gardner%20%28botanist%29">Charles Gardner</a>, the species was at one stage considered a <a href="Variety%20%28botany%29">variety</a> of "<a href="Banksia%20sphaerocarpa">B. sphaerocarpa</a>". Although there are no recognised subspecies or varieties, both <a href="lignotuber">lignotuber</a>ous and nonlignotuberous forms exist for "Banksia violacea". Wasps, ants and flies have been recorded visiting flower spikes. "Banksia violacea" is classified as Not Threatened under the <a href="Wildlife%20Conservation%20Act%201950">Wildlife Conservation Act of Western Australia</a>. Regarded as of little value to <a href="floriculture">floriculture</a>, it is rarely cultivated.
Description.
"Banksia violacea" grows as a shrub up to 1.5 m (5 ft) tall, with narrow leaves 1–2 cm (0.4–0.8 in) long and about 0.15 cm (0.06 in) wide. New growth occurs in summer, and flowering ranges from November to April with a peak in February, but can be irregular in timing. Flowers arise from typical "Banksia" "flower <a href="raceme">spikes</a>", and the <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a>s are made up of hundreds of pairs of flowers densely packed in a <a href="helix">spiral</a> around a woody axis. Roughly spherical with a diameter of 2–3 cm (0.8–1.2 in), the flower spikes arise from lateral stems lie partly within the foliage. Unusually for "Banksia" species, the inflorescences are often <a href="violet%20%28color%29">violet</a> in colour, ranging anywhere from a dark violet-black through various combinations of violet and greenish-yellow in less pigmented blooms. Each flower consists of a tubular <a href="perianth">perianth</a> made up of four fused <a href="tepal">tepal</a>s, and one long wiry <a href="carpel">style</a>. The styles are hooked rather than straight, and are initially trapped inside the upper perianth parts, but break free at <a href="anthesis">anthesis</a>. The old flowers gradually fade to brown. The fruiting structure or <a href="Follicle%20%28fruit%29">follicle</a> is a stout woody "cone", with a hairy appearance caused by the persistence of old withered flower parts. These follicles are crowded around the globular spike (called an infructescence at this point) and are oval to rhomboid, although the crowding makes some irregularly shaped. They measure 1–2.5 cm (0.4–1 in) long, 0.6 cm (0.2 in) high and 0.8–2.2 cm (0.3–0.9 in) wide. They are quite flattened and lack a ridge along the valve line. When young, the follicles are greenish in colour and slightly sticky, and covered in fine white hairs, fading to tan or grey with age. They open with fire, releasing a winged wedge-shaped (cuneate) seed 2–2.5 cm (0.8–1 in) long. The mottled dark grey seed body is falcate (crescent-shaped) and measures 1.2–1.8 cm (0.5–0.7 in) long and 0.2–0.25 cm (0.1 in) wide, with a flattened dark brown wing 1.1–1.7 cm (0.4–0.5 in) wide. The woody <a href="Seed%20separator">separator</a> has the same dimensions as the seed.
The bright green <a href="cotyledon">cotyledon</a> leaves of the seedlings are oblong to linear in shape and measure 1.5 cm (0.6 in) long by 0.3 cm (0.1 in) wide. The greenish red <a href="hypocotyl">hypocotyl</a> is hairy, as are the stems of young plants. The hairy seedling leaves are crowded and oppositely arranged. They measure 0.7–1.3 cm (0.2–0.5 in) in length and have recurved margins. Young plants often begin branching within their first year of life.
Taxonomy.
The <a href="holotype">type specimen</a> of "Banksia violacea" was collected by the West Australian botanist <a href="Charles%20Gardner%20%28botanist%29">Charles Gardner</a> on 14 December 1926 in the vicinity of <a href="Lake%20Grace">Lake Grace</a>. The following year, he published a description of the species in "<a href="Journal%20and%20Proceedings%20of%20the%20Royal%20Society%20of%20Western%20Australia">Journal and Proceedings of the Royal Society of Western Australia</a>". He placed it in <a href="Section%20%28botany%29">section</a> "<a href="Banksia%20sect.%20Oncostylis">Oncostylis</a>" of <a href="Bentham%27s%20taxonomic%20arrangement%20of%20Banksia">Bentham's taxonomic arrangement of "Banksia"</a>, giving it the <a href="specific%20name%20%28botany%29">specific epithet</a> "violacea" in reference to the violet flowers. Thus the full name of the species, with author citation, is "Banksia violacea" C.A.Gardner. The species has been considered a <a href="Variety%20%28botany%29">variety</a> of "<a href="Banksia%20sphaerocarpa">B. sphaerocarpa</a>" (Fox Banksia); this view was published by <a href="William%20Blackall">William Blackall</a> in his 1954 "<a href="How%20to%20know%20Western%20Australian%20wildflowers">How to know Western Australian wildflowers</a>". He considered "B. violacea" to be a variety of "B. sphaerocarpa" with violet flowers. This description was an invalid publication, however, and a "<a href="nomen%20nudum">nomen nudum</a>". In 1981 <a href="Alex%20George">Alex George</a> declared "Banksia sphaerocarpa" var. "violacea" Blackall a nomenclatural <a href="synonym%20%28taxonomy%29">synonym</a> of "B. violacea".
In George's 1981 arrangement, "B. violacea" was placed in <a href="Banksia%20subg.%20Banksia">subgenus "Banksia"</a> because its inflorescence is a typical "Banksia" "flower spike"; <a href="Banksia%20sect.%20Oncostylis">section "Oncostylis"</a> because of its hooked <a href="carpel">style</a>s; and <a href="Banksia%20ser.%20Abietinae">series "Abietinae"</a> because its inflorescence is roughly spherical. It was placed in <a href="taxonomic%20sequence">taxonomic sequence</a> between "<a href="Banksia%20incana">B. incana</a>" (Hoary Banksia) and "<a href="Banksia%20meisneri">B. meisneri</a>" (Meissner's Banksia).
In 1996, <a href="Kevin%20Thiele">Kevin Thiele</a> and <a href="Pauline%20Ladiges">Pauline Ladiges</a> published the results of a <a href="cladistics">cladistic</a> analysis of <a href="morphology%20%28biology%29">morphological</a> characters of "Banksia". They retained George's subgenera and many of his series, but discarded his sections. "B." ser. "Abietinae" was found to be very nearly <a href="monophyly">monophyletic</a> and so it was retained. It further resolved into four subclades, so Thiele and Ladiges split it into four <a href="subseries">subseries</a>. "B. violacea" appeared in the last of these:
This clade became the basis of <a href="Banksia%20subser.%20Longistyles">"B." subseries "Longistyles"</a>, which Thiele defined as containing those taxa with very long and slender styles, smoothly convex perianth limbs without a costal ridge, and thickened margins. In accordance with their <a href="cladogram">cladogram</a>, their arrangement placed "B. violacea" first in taxonomic sequence, followed by "<a href="Banksia%20laricina">B. laricina</a>" (Rose-fruited Banksia). However, Thiele and Ladiges' arrangement was not accepted by George, who, questioning the emphasis on cladistics, rejected most of their changes in <a href="George%27s%20taxonomic%20arrangement%20of%20Banksia">his 1999 arrangement</a>, restored "B." series "Abietinae" to his broader 1981 definition, and abandoned all of Thiele and Ladiges' subseries. George commented that the species has no close relatives, being "loosely allied" to "<a href="Banksia%20sphaerocarpa">B. sphaerocarpa</a>" (Fox Banksia) and "<a href="Banksia%20telmatiaea">B. telmatiaea</a>" (Swamp Fox Banksia). Despite this, the sequence of the series was altered so that "B. violacea" fell between "<a href="Banksia%20scabrella">B. scabrella</a>" (Burma Road Banksia) and "B. incana", and its placement in George's arrangement may be summarised as follows:
Since 1998, an American botanist, <a href="Austin%20Mast">Austin Mast</a>, has been publishing results of ongoing cladistic analyses of <a href="DNA%20sequence">DNA sequence</a> data for the subtribe <a href="Banksiinae">Banksiinae</a>. His analyses suggest a phylogeny that is very greatly different from George's arrangement, and somewhat different from Thiele and Ladiges'. With respect to "B. violacea", Mast's results agree with its placement near "B. laricina" and "B. incana", placing it in a clade with these two species and <a href="Banksia%20sphaerocarpa%20var.%20dolichostyla">"B. sphaerocarpa" var. "dolichostyla"</a> (treated at species rank as "B. dolichostyla"). However, Thiele's "B." subseries "Longistyles" appears to be <a href="polyphyly">polyphyletic</a>, as do both definitions of "B." ser. "Abietinae"—that is, none form a natural grouping.
Early in 2007, Mast and Thiele initiated a rearrangement of "Banksia" by merging "<a href="Dryandra">Dryandra</a>" into it, and publishing <a href="Banksia%20subg.%20Spathulatae">"B." subgenus "Spathulatae"</a> for the taxa having spoon-shaped <a href="cotyledon">cotyledon</a>s. They foreshadowed publishing a full arrangement once DNA sampling of "Dryandra" was complete; in the meantime, if Mast and Thiele's nomenclatural changes are taken as an interim arrangement, then "B. violacea" is placed in "B." subgenus "Spathulatae".
Distribution and habitat.
"B. violacea" occurs in southern regions of Western Australia, from <a href="Woodanilling%2C%20Western%20Australia">Woodanilling</a> to <a href="Esperance%2C%20Western%20Australia">Esperance</a> and as far north as <a href="Hyden%2C%20Western%20Australia">Hyden</a>. This distribution includes areas of the <a href="Avon%20Wheatbelt">Avon Wheatbelt</a>, <a href="Esperance%20Plains">Esperance Plains</a> and <a href="Mallee%20%28biogeographic%20region%29">Mallee</a> <a href="biogeography">biogeographic</a> regions. It favours white <a href="sand">sand</a>y soils, often overlying <a href="laterite">laterite</a>, <a href="clay">clay</a> or <a href="quartzite">quartzite</a>. It usually grows among <a href="heath%20%28habitat%29">heath</a> and <a href="shrubland">shrubland</a>s, associated with <a href="mallee%20%28habit%29">mallee</a> eucalypts and <a href="Banksia%20sphaerocarpa%20var.%20caesia">"Banksia sphaerocarpa" var. "caesia"</a>. "Banksia violacea" is classified as Not Threatened under the 1950 <a href="Wildlife%20Conservation%20Act%201950">Wildlife Conservation Act of Western Australia</a>.
Ecology.
Like most other <a href="Proteaceae">Proteaceae</a>, "Banksia violacea" has <a href="proteoid%20root">proteoid root</a>s, roots with dense clusters of short lateral rootlets that form a mat in the soil just below the leaf litter. These enhance solubilisation of nutrients, thus allowing their uptake in low-nutrient soils such as the <a href="phosphorus">phosphorus</a>-deficient soils of Australia. "B. violacea" is highly susceptible to "<a href="Phytophthora%20cinnamomi">Phytophthora cinnamomi</a>" dieback.
"Banksia violacea" is one of a small number of "Banksia" species that has both <a href="lignotuber">lignotuber</a>ous and non-lignotuberous populations. In both cases, plants are adapted to release their <a href="aerial%20seed%20bank">aerial seed bank</a> following a <a href="Bushfires%20in%20Australia">bushfire</a>, ensuring seedlings are established on clear and relatively fertile ground; however the possession of a lignotuber makes plants much less reliant on fire regime for population maintenance and regeneration, as maternal plants are not killed by bushfire, but resprout from below ground level. Lignotuberous plants generally occur among the north-eastern populations, in the vicinity of <a href="Woodanilling%2C%20Western%20Australia">Woodanilling</a>. An investigation into the <a href="biogeography">biogeography</a> of these plants failed to find any vegetative, climatic or other environmental factors associated with the possession of a lignotuber.
Banksia flowerheads in general play host to a variety of birds, mammals and insects. However, only wasps, ants and flies were recorded visiting flower spikes during observations for "<a href="The%20Banksia%20Atlas">The Banksia Atlas</a>" in the mid-1980s.
Cultivation.
"Banksia violacea" is rarely cultivated. It is a slow-growing plant that tends to become untidy with age, and generally does not flower until four to five years after sprouting from seed. Flowers are an unusual colour, but occur within the bush where they grow within and are usually obscured by foliage. It tolerates light <a href="pruning">pruning</a> not below the green foliage, except for the variant with a lignotuber, which may be pruned heavily. George recommends a sunny position in light, sandy soil. Professor Margaret Bernard Sedgley of the <a href="University%20of%20Adelaide%23Waite">Waite Institute</a> suggests the species is of no value to <a href="floriculture">floriculture</a>, as the inflorescences are too small and obscured by the foliage, although she does add that the purple colour may be a worthwhile character to select for in <a href="plant%20breeding">plant breeding</a>. Seeds do not require any treatment, and take 19 to 50 days to <a href="germinate">germinate</a>.
